name: Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic Acid)
summary: Vitamin B5, also known as pantothenic acid, is an essential water-soluble vitamin that plays a critical role in energy metabolism and synthesis of coenzyme A (CoA).
description: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) is a member of the B-complex vitamins, necessary for the synthesis of coenzyme A, a central cofactor in the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. It is also involved in the synthesis of fatty acids, cholesterol, steroid hormones, acetylcholine, and hemoglobin. Deficiency is rare due to its widespread presence in foods, but when it occurs, it may lead to fatigue, irritability, numbness, muscle cramps, and the so-called 'burning feet syndrome.' Vitamin B5 is sometimes supplemented for stress reduction, skin health, and wound healing, though clinical evidence is limited.

metadata.natural_source: Meat, poultry, fish, eggs, legumes, whole grains, mushrooms, avocados, broccoli

primary_indications: Treatment and prevention of pantothenic acid deficiency
off_label_uses: Support for skin health and wound healing

items: Treatment and prevention of pantothenic acid deficiency
Topical use of panthenol in skin and hair care products

sections.text: Vitamin B5 is essential for the synthesis of coenzyme A (CoA) and acyl carrier protein, both of which are central to fatty acid synthesis and metabolism. CoA is also necessary for acetylation reactions, cholesterol and steroid synthesis, and neurotransmitter production (acetylcholine).

adult.clinical: Higher doses (up to several grams) have been studied for acne and stress, but evidence is limited

sections.text: Supports metabolic processes continuously; deficiency symptoms improve within days to weeks of supplementation.

common: Mild gastrointestinal upset at high doses
serious: None well documented at standard supplementation doses

other: Deficiency is rare in humans, usually seen only in severe malnutrition or experimental restriction.
High-dose supplementation has not been shown to provide additional health benefits in most people.

items.risk: Competitive absorption in very high doses
items.action: Monitor if supplementing with large doses of both

items: No routine monitoring required for typical supplementation

sections.text: Not required; vitamin supplementation can be stopped without tapering.

items: Pantothenic acid deficiency is extremely rare due to its wide distribution in foods.
Dexpanthenol (a derivative of pantothenic acid) is sometimes used clinically to stimulate intestinal movements after surgery.
Panthenol is widely used in cosmetic products for moisturizing and improving skin and hair appearance.
